Just wondering... In your implementation, if you do not use innovation numbers, how do you line up genes for mating operations?  

Robert Ziegler <rziegler42@...> wrote:    I wrote most of an implementation in C++ under OS-X,
 but haven't had time to finish it yet.  It is done
 enough to solve the xor problem, but the mating
 functions are still buggy.  The code was written from
 the papers rather than copying existing source.  It is
 very fast and efficient, compared to the other code I
 have seen, but it is also fairly buggy and incomplete.
  
 
 I also made one major deviation, programatically, from
 neat... there are no innovation numbers... at least
 not directly.  Innovation is still implemented, but
 done so in a much more efficient manner.  However,
 this change causes problems in the speciation section.
  Speciation works, but is a bit unstable... sometimes
 the number of species will sky rocket... this may be a
 bug, or a design flaw (on my part), I'm not yet sure.
 
 If you have questions specific to coding Mac OS-X with
 x-code in C++ or Objective-C, I can probably help you
 out.
 
 --- Adam Wright <zeno@...> wrote:
 
 > Hi,
 > 
 > I'm extremely new here. Although I'm actually a bit
 > shocked it took  
 > me as long to find NEAT as it did, as it's the kind
 > of thing I've  
 > been quite interested in for years.
 > 
 > Rather, it took until I came to write a proposal for
 > an honours year  
 > project, when a potential supervisor pointed me
 > towards NEAT after I  
 > spent a few minutes ranting at them about the kind
 > of things I was  
 > interested in.
 > 
 > Anyway, now I'm hopefully going to be able to spend
 > my year doing  
 > NEAT related things.
 > 
 > At the moment, I've yet to get the original NEAT
 > package to  
 > compile... Because I'm trying to do so under OS X...
 > Since while it  
 > would be possible to use Linux all year, I'd
 > *vastly* prefer to sit  
 > in front of a mac.
 > 
 > So far, I think I've got everything I need via fink
 > and I've changed  
 > paths in the Makefile appropriately, but just
 > compilation of  
 > networks.cpp throws the to-be-expected screens and
 > screens of errors...
 > 
 > Searching the list archive suggests I'm out of luck
 > as far as finding  
 > an empathetic ear is concerned, but I just thought
 > before I spend  
 > hours trying to get this thing to work, I'd see if
 > anyone else has  
 > had any luck? =)
 > 
 > Thanks,
 > 
 > --
 >   Adam Wright  <zeno@...>
 >   University Website Office, The University of
 > Western Australia
 > 
 > 
 >
